bullets.content: Bowl + spoon
Food
Bib
Highchair
Baby wipes/cloth
Microwave/stove

sections.content: Judging the amount of food is hard at first. A baby at four months can eat anywhere between 1-3 tablespoons of food at 1-2 ‘meals’, in addition to bottles or breastfeeding. By six months, it’ll be around 4 teaspoons, 3 times a day. The guideline is, feed until the kid has had enough. You’ll get to know your baby’s appetite.

bullets.content: Heat the food up in the microwave or on the stove.
Taste it to check the temperature. It should be warm, but not too warm.
Put the baby in the high chair and make sure that it’s secure.
Fasten the bib comfortably around the neck; this is going to get messy.
Keep at it until the baby lets you know their done.
Take off the bib.
Using the baby wipes, clean their hands and face.
Take the baby out of the high chair and put it somewhere safe.
Give the high chair a good wipe down.
leave your baby alone in the highchair.

sections.content:
Weaning

The baby should always be sitting up straight and facing you

Be regular. Keep meal times close to the same time every day.

Feeding the baby when you and your partner are also eating can help get their interest. When babies see you eating they tend to want some too.

Start introducing food by offering few teaspoons a day or a single piece of soft fruit

Let the baby touch and hold the food to get used to it.

Make sure the the temperature is correct.

Take your time. You’ll need some patience
Nothing beats the aeroplane maneuver.

Warning Sign

You’ll get to know your baby’s feeding patterns. If it refuses to eat or shows no interest in food over the course of a couple of days, you should contact your GP.

Generic

I can put any html in here

bullets.heading: Baby food has to be easy to digest, smooth and not strongly flavoured.
bullets.content: Fruit – Soft fruit or vegetables that your baby can hold in their hand.
Puréed root vegetables – Potato, parsnips, sweet potato. You could throw in some mashed pear or apple too for added flavour.
Mashed rice – Mix the rice and mash it with the baby’s regular milk to make ‘baby rice’.
Avoid – Sugar, salt, honey, raw shellfish and whole nuts.

sections.content: Fresh is best. Try not to rely on processed baby food except for emergencies. You’ve already learned how to cook during your partner’s pregnancy, now learn to cook healthy, tasty baby food.

Baby Proofing your home

The good news is that your baby won’t be too mobile in the first six months. But it will get mobile soon, and possibly unpredictably.

Make sure that your living room, kitchen, nursery and any other areas that your baby is likely to spend time in, are generally safe. No unstable book shelves, piles of art materials, Xboxes with wires that you could trip on – look at your place with a critical eye.

Later on you’ll need to go much further in providing a safe environment for your kid. But here are the basics…

bullets.content: Smoke alarm.
Carbon Monoxide alarm – make sure that it's fitted to the manufacturer's guidelines.

sections.content: If you already have alarms installed, now is a good time to have them checked.

bullets.content: Safety gates – At the top and bottom of the stairs.
Plastic caps – For electrical sockets.
Child proof door locks – For both house doors and internal doors.
Medicines – Any that you’d commonly leave around on tables should be secured away. That goes for multivitamins too.
Thick carpet – Or a rug on the floor for bumps and falls.
Night light – So you can see where you’re going in the dark.
Finger pinch guards – So doors won’t close on their hands.

sections.content:
The Baby

The fertalised egg attaches itself to the wall of the womb. It starts off as just one cell, which quickly multiplies. Until week eight, it’s technically known as an embryo. By then all of the major organs will be place and medically it’s referred to as a feotus. You’ll call it ‘the baby’.

Your baby will grow from microscopic size at conception, to the size of a plum by week eight. By week 12 it’ll be about 7.5-10cm long and weigh a whopping 28g.

Your Partner

Every pregnancy is different but the flood of new hormones is likely to cause some issues, and for many women (and therefore men) the first trimester is the least enjoyable. Most of the really uncomfortable symptoms take place over the first 12 weeks: tiredness, heartburn, indigestion, wind, constipation and sensitivity to odours. Your partner is also likely to suffer from morning sickness, which is a misleadingly named ailment because it can last all day.

There’s usually no signs of a bump at this point, which can give the whole experience an air of unreality. But trust the baby scans.

bullets.content: Adjusting diet and lifestyle.
Telling your GP.
First scan at eight weeks.

sections.content:
Warning signs

Unfortunately, this is the stage of pregnancy when the risk of miscarriage is at its highest. In most cases it’s a natural occurrence because the foetus is not developing correctly. You should consult your GP at the first sign of any abdominal pains or unusual bleeding. Be vigilant. But also try not to worry.

You

Your partner will be doing most of the baby work for the next 40 weeks, but that doesn’t mean you’re off the hook. You have a little over nine months to get ready for the biggest change you’ll ever experience in life. The time to start making the adjustment is right now, Daddyo.

Be kind

It’s pretty likely that your partner is going to have some mood swings. This is normal. Be smart about it and try to rise. Your partner could be equally frustrated by how she feels. Stay calm to diffuse the tension and gain kudos in the long run.

Do stuff

That means cleaning, vacuuming, shopping, laundry and all the other things you probably hate doing. If your partner is the clean freak in your relationship try to meet her at least halfway on standards. Pre-empting arguments about this can be a real win. (if you’re the clean freak, then carry on with what you’re doing.)

Get fit

The next while is going to be physically demanding getting into a routine of a little extra exercise pays off in the long run. Join a gym. Do a bootcamp. Go jogging. Start cycling. It all helps. It’ll probably give you some time to think too, which can be nice.

Make a budget

Figure out the numbers. A new kid is expensive and you may need to make some changes now to afford things down the track.

Lifestyle

You’re probably going to need to be a bit more responsible about your time. That could mean cutting down on the lads nights out, or not spending three weekends away a month rock climbing.

Learn how to cook

An incredibly useful skill. If you know how to cook already, that’s great. Now learn how to cook for a pregnant lady and a baby.

What are they?

Ultrasound scans use sound waves to create a picture of the baby in the womb. The sonographer, the person who conducts the test, will put some gel on your partner’s tummy and run a small device over it. The device emits high-frequency sound waves that the machine converts into a picture of your baby on a TV screen. The sonographer will explain the picture to you. There’s generally two scans.

First scan, 8-14 weeks

This scan is used to ‘date’ the baby to see how it’s growing.

Second scan, 18-21 weeks

This is more detailed scan, which checks for major physical problems. The sonographer may also be able to tell you the sex of your baby, if they can make it out.

bullets.content: The baby’s size – And its development. The sonographer will be able to point our arms and legs.

The baby’s gender – Talk to you partner before you go in for the scan about whether or not you want to know the sex of the baby. There’s not that many real surprises in life – but then again, knowing this might help you deck out the nursery.
Multiple babies – Yes. It happens. One in eight pregnancies results in twins. Be mentally prepared.
Physical abnormalities – The sonographer or doctor will advise you if there are any issues.
Baby position – This is only a factor in later stages of the pregnancy.

sections.content: Some private clinics offer additional ultrasound scans or 3D scans. It’s amazing to see what the foetus is up to in there – for you, at least. Your friends aren’t going to understand the fascination.

Food Safety

The best diet during pregnancy is a balanced and nutritious one that promotes steady weight gain. Your partner shouldn’t be concerned about putting on weight but equally, that’s not an excuse to go to town on takeaways.

It’s generally recommended that your partner eats every three hours and drinks plenty of water. Do not encourage her to ‘eat enough for two’. It’s not necessary. She should just enough for healthy weight gain.
As always, if your partner experiences anything that you’re concerned about – chronic vomiting, loss of appetite, whatever – visit your GP.

bullets.heading: LEAN MEATS
bullets.content: Baked, boiled or grilled.

bullets.heading: POULTRY (FULLY COOKED)
bullets.content: Healthy low fat protein.

bullets.heading: EGGS (FULLY COOKED)
bullets.content: They’re brilliant.

bullets.heading: FRUIT
bullets.content: Going crazy on fruit can help with constipation.

bullets.heading: VEGETABLES
bullets.content: No brainer.

bullets.heading: CEREALS
bullets.content: Choose whole grains whenever possible.

bullets.heading: NUTS
bullets.content: Great for healthy fats and protein.

bullets.heading: MILK
bullets.content: For calcium. You can also get calcium from fortified OJ, cheeses, soup made from proper chicken stock and sardines.

bullets.heading: ALCOHOL
bullets.content: In general, your partner should cut out the booze.

bullets.heading: LIVER
bullets.content: Has some great qualities, but it can contain too much vitamin A.

bullets.heading: PATE
bullets.content: High risk of Listeria.

bullets.heading: SWORDFISH, MARLIN, SHARK
bullets.content: Too high in mercury.

bullets.heading: HOT DOGS
bullets.content: High risk of Listeria.

bullets.heading: LUNCHEON MEATS
bullets.content: High risk of Listeria.

bullets.heading: CURED MEATS (PARMA, PROSCUITTO)
bullets.content: Risk of listeriosis, toxoplamosis.

bullets.heading: SALAMIS
bullets.content: Risk of listeriosis & toxoplamosis.

bullets.heading: UNCOOKED SMOKED SEAFOOD
bullets.content: Fine when cooked.

bullets.heading: RAW MILK
bullets.content: Risk of Listeria and salmonella.

bullets.heading: CERTAIN CHEESES
bullets.content: (soft, blue vein, mould ripened) same as raw milk.

bullets.heading: CIGARETTES
bullets.content: Yes, it’s not a food but we’re putting it in here while we’re talking about things to give up. If she’s a smoker, quitting is going to be really tough on your partner, so you’ll have to be supportive. If you smoke too, it’d be a good move to join in and quit. There’s no better motivation than a baby on the way.

bullets.heading: BUTTER AND CREAM
bullets.content: Limit your intake. It’s safe, but unhealthy.

bullets.heading: SALT
bullets.content: Totally fine in moderation. Just try to avoid processed food.

bullets.heading: TUNA
bullets.content: Once or twice a week max. High but generally safe level of mercury.

bullets.heading: CAFFEINE
bullets.content: Try to limit to one coffee a day.

sections.content: Preferably alcohol should be avoided during pregnancy. There are serious risks associated with it, including restricted growth, facial abnormalities and learning disorders. Having said that, the highest risk is during the first three months of the pregnancy and there is some disagreement on whether or not there is a safe level of consumption. One or two units (that’s about half a glass of wine) a week after the first trimester may be OK. But it’s best to play it safe though and avoid completely. If it removes temptation, support your partner and cut back your own intake.

What is it?

Morning sickness is the common name for Nausea and Vomiting in Pregnancy (NVP) that most women experience at some point in the first trimester of pregnancy. Around half of all pregnant women will experience full-on morning sickness, while another third will have frequent bouts of nausea. So it’s very likely that your partner will be affected by it. The good new is that it usually has subsided by week 14.

There’s no definite answer on the cause of morning sickness but the consensus is that the most likely culprit is the dramatic hormonal changes that your partner’s body is going through.

Your partner might be one of the lucky ones and escape with only mild symptoms, or maybe none at all. If that’s the case, thank your lucky stars and don’t gloat over other less fortunate fathers-to-be.

Morning sickness doesn’t just happen in the morning. It can onset at any time of the day or night. It can last for just a short time, or all day long. For some women it’s a minor inconvenience, for others it can be debilitating.

For a while at least, it’s probably going to be just one of those things.

What to do

Care – It’s easy to forget how much nausea sucks. If you notice that your partner is looking a little down or peeky, ask is she’s alright or if you can help with anything. If you can, great. If not, then at least she knows you care.

Rest –Encourage your partner to rest. More rest, usually mean less vomiting. Doing an extra 20-30 minutes of the daily chores can go a long way.

Eat in bed – If your partner is vomiting or ill in the morning, she should get up slowly. She could try to have something plain to eat. Dry toast or crackers can be good.

Food smells – Expectant mothers can acquire a superhuman sense of smell, which can bring on morning sickness. Also the scent of food can trigger nausea. Fish is a common trigger, so are beer and garlic. Every woman is different and some foods that she used to love will be intolerable now. Consider eating cold meals more often as the smells tend not to be as strong.

Citrus – The smell of lemons and oranges can sometimes reduce nausea.

Drinks – Drink lots of fluids and stay hydrated. However, avoid drinks that are too cold or sharp tasting.

Frequent small meals – This is often better than having two large meals. Eat foods that are high in carbohydrates eg. pasta, bread, rice, etc. Spicy, sweet food might be harder to keep down than plain, savoury foods.

Loose waisted clothes – Your partner should wear something comfortable; tight waist bands can increase nausea.

Ginger biscuits, ginger ale or ginger supplements might alleviate the symptoms, as long as they contain real ginger. Just make sure, particularly with the supplements, that you are buying from a reputable source.
Aftershave has an extremely strong smell that can be a trigger for morning sickness. Put the bottle away, if it’s a problem.

Morning sickness is more likely to occur when your partner is tired and emotional. As she may not have told her family and friends that she’s pregnant, you’re the one on-call to support. As no one probably knows that your partner is pregnant yet, keep a couple of excuses handy to explain why you’re both suddenly leaving parties in a hurry.

Warning signs

Some women experience severe or extreme morning sickness, which is called hyperemesis gravidarum. If your partner is chronically and violently ill, get medical advice. She may need to be treated in hospital.

Watch out for – Dizzy or faint spells; very dark urine; stomach pains; high temperatures; or blood in vomit.

What are they?

Pregnancy is often associated with food cravings. They often have a sudden onset and can be quite intense. It could be a craving for something that your partner normally likes, normally doesn’t like, or something that’s downright weird. (Alternatively, your partner might go off foods that she used to love.)
You can make them work for you – a well-timed trip to an Indian takeaway for a curry craving can earn you a lot of good will.

What causes them?

There’s no consensus on what causes cravings. They usually start in the first trimester, are at their strongest in the second, and have generally subsided before the birth of the baby.

It’s common for women to crave dairy products, sweet foods or salty foods including pickles. Unless it’s explicitly against medical advice, your partner should feel free to satisfy them. Stock the fridge and have takeaway menus to hand.
Any cravings your partner normally has are likely to continue, whether they’re harmful (nicotine), or not so harmful (chocolate). Obviously, the harmful cravings should be ignored.

Finances

Babies are expensive. But how much you spend is totally up to you and your partner. Like buying a car, you can get a fully kitted out Porsche, or go for an ultra-reliable Toyota that will get the job done just as well.

As a general rule, don’t get carried away. There are lots of good quality, good value products out there. Do some market research online and shop around.

Whether you do a budget now or not, you will need to do one for the next year.

Regular chats

You and your partner should set aside time to talk about the figures. Once a month, once every two weeks. Whatever is needed. Stick the dates in the diary and keep to them. You could hold these meet ups in a café or a quiet bar if that makes them less painful.

bullets.heading: Income changes
bullets.content: Benefit entitlements
Loss of earnings (maternity, paternity leave)
Tax changes

bullets.heading: Costs
bullets.content: Birth Medical bills – Obstetrics fees
Post natal GP care
Childcare costs – Worth thinking about early.
Home improvements – Baby proofing/decor.
Sleeping kit – Cots, nightlights, baby monitors.
Nappies – Lots and lots of these.
Car – Is what you drive now appropriate?
Car seat – You will need one car seat for the first 12 months or so, and then another larger one.
Buggy – You might have a  travel system (a car seat buggy combo) but you’ll need another all-purpose buggy at a later stage.

sections.content: Saving from day one is a good idea. Even if you’ve been planning for a while, use the nine months to get a budget in place that allows you to put a few quid away. Not everyone can afford to do so, but if you can it’ll take some pressure off later.

People don’t need buggies and baby gear forever. Savvy shoppers can pick up great deals on second hand gear, and hand-me-downs are likely to be offered by friends and family. Just make sure that you are satisfied that the items are safe and in good nick. Never buy a second hand car seat.

Make a list of all the major purchases and buy one of them every month for the duration of the pregnancy. It’ll be weird buying a bottle steriliser six months in advance but do it now and you won’t have a giant last minute panic-shop.

Cooking

This may seem like a small thing but there’s lots of good reasons to brush up on your cooking skills..

Win win

1. If you take responsibility for most of the cooking, it’ll take pressure off your partner during the pregnancy, which gives her more time to rest. More rest, generally means less of the bad pregnancy stuff. So win win.

Save cash

2. If you don’t usually cook at home already, you’ll find that you’re saving yourselves some cash.

Healthier

3. You’ll know exactly what you’re eating from a nutritional point of view, meaning you can both make good choices.

Faster

4. When you’re both tired you’ll be able to cook something healthy, fast. Or better still, you’ll have stuff in the freezer ready to be microwaved.

Kudos

5. You’ll get kudos. Lots and lots of kudos.

bullets.content: Focus on simple meals – It’s better to get the basics right than learn how to plan elaborate dinner parties. Start with pasta dishes, stews, soups and salads. Lasagne and chilli freeze particularly well. Anything that can be made one-handed while carrying a baby.
Cook to order – Learn how to cook your partner’s favourite things.

Collect recipes – There are tons of great sites out there. BBC Food, the Guardian Life & Style section, and Epicurious are excellent resources for healthy quick meals. Keep a note of the ones that work.
Classes – Cooking lessons can be expensive. However beginners classes can be a good way to get you started.

Baby cook books – Although you won’t need it right away, learning to cook healthy tasty food for you baby is a great way to ensure they’re getting the nutrition they need. And it feels brilliant when you’ve cooked something healthy that your kid loves.

sections.content: The Baby

From week 12th to week 18-20. The baby is now putting on about 100g a week in weight, and in the last few weeks of the trimester the baby will be almost fully formed. It’ll also start being very active in the womb. Expect the first kick sometime between weeks 16 and 20.

Some women experience feotal movements even earlier, which are called quickening or flutters.

Your Partner

The good news is that your partner’s morning sickness has probably eased off. However, she’s still likely to suffer from heartburn, indigestion as well as constipation, varicose veins, hemorrhoids and general aches and pains. Yes, the going can get tough.

Your partner’s body is going through a lot of changes in a very short space of time, so as she’s getting bigger she may get some stretch marks. She might be self-conscious or unhappy about all of this. Do a good job of making her feel good about herself. Most stretch marks reduce after giving birth.
The bump will start showing and as the morning sickness and other symptoms subside, your partner may find she’s enjoying this trimester more than the first. So you should too.

bullets.content: Telling your family and friends
Flutters
First kick
Unusual abdominal pain
Vaginal bleeding
Chronic nausea or vomiting

sections.content:
When to announce

The tradition is to wait until twelve weeks from conception before telling your family and friends that you’re going to have a baby.

It’s more than tradition. The majority of miscarriages happen in the first three months. It can be hard enough to cope with this as a couple without having the added pressure of telling the bad news to everyone. So resist the temptation as much as possible.

Many couples make the choice not to tell the big news until after their first scan. You’ll both probably be really excited to spread the word as quickly as possible but to avoid hurt feelings tell agree together to tell people in order.

Assuming that you’re lucky enough to have all of the following, The Daddyo recommended announcement order is:

bullets.content: 1. Both sets of parents
2. Brothers, sisters and close friends
3. Aunts, uncles, cousins
4. Colleagues & anyone else.

sections.content: If you feel the need to share your news over Facebook, only do it after you’ve gone through this list. Family members might find it hurtful to find out third hand that they’re going to have a new relation.

Book your paternity leave/holidays from work. You may need to ask for some flexibility, as the birth could happen a couple of weeks before or after the due date and you might have to duck out on very short notice. Nevertheless, having these dates down in the work diary makes everything feel a lot more real.

Picking names

When couples start thinking of having kids they play the what’ll-we-name-our-kids game. It can be a lot less fun when you’re playing for keeps and both parties start playing rough.
To keep it clean, and to keep arguments to a minimum, here’s the rules to the Daddyo baby name game.

Phases

Research phase

Go through a ‘research phase’. Get inspiration from books, movies, wherever. (Ironman is not a name) Have a time limit on this part – a week, a month, it doesn’t matter. Although, it’s probably a good idea to do it a bit before the due date.

Top 10 lists

On a pre-arranged day, both you and your partner each make a top 10 list of your favourite names. Five boys’ names, five girls’ names. If you already know the gender of the baby, you only get five names in total.

Swap lists

Swap the lists over. You each get two vetoes, one for each gender, and you get to cross the offending names off the list your partner made.

Ranking

Now rank the remaining names from your partner’s selection in your order of preference. Working together, eliminate names by:

Too popular?

Checking the remaining choices against the current most popular current children’s names. You probably don’t want your baby’s name to be too common.

Family name?

Noting any family connections to any of the names – would a connection be a good thing or a bad thing?

Too cute?

Asking if any of the names are cute for a kid, but odd for a grown man or woman?

Bully-proof?

Looking for negative connotations for the names, either historically or in fiction? Do they rhyme with anything that could lead to a schoolyard annoyance.

Swap back

Check what’s left on both lists and take it in turns to make the case for the remaining names from your own list.
Finding any common ground yet?

Start over

If you still can’t agree, go back to step one. This time around you’re only allowed to take one name from your previous selection.
Good luck!
After all of this, be ready to change – when you meet your baby, the name you’ve spent all this time fighting over may not seem to fit.

Antenatal classes are parental cramming sessions that you usually attend between 8-10 weeks before the due date. They’re supposed to prepare you for the birth itself and the early stages of parenting. Of course, nothing will prepare you fully for it.

However, it’s generally true that soon-to-be dads find it a more useful than their partners (often because the mums have done their homework better). Make the most of these classes because they are genuinely useful.
This is going to be a crash course, so pay attention. And take notes.

sections.title: Depending on the class, you’ll cover

bullets.content: Birth choices available – Hospital, home birth, private, semi-private, etc.
Birth plans – What they are, how to make one.
Labour – How to recognise it, what to do.
Pain relief – From prescription medicine to massage techniques and everything in between.
Relaxation tips – Which can be key to a smooth birth.
Breathing techniques – Mostly for your partner, but during labour you might need some reminding too.
Birthing balls –  You’ll find out what they are and might be allowed to try one out, if you’re lucky.
Birth interventions – What happens when things get complicated.
How tos – stay healthy, feed a baby, hold a baby, and more.
Emotional wellbeing – for both you and your partner.

sections.content: You’ll also be able to discuss your concerns and ask questions.
Sign up to these classes early in pregnancy. They can fill up quickly and you don’t need the stress of telling your partner at week 30 that you never booked them.
The Baby

Week 18 to birth (usually between weeks 38-40). There’ll be less kicking and activity over the course of this trimester – mostly because the growing baby is running out of space in the womb. Your kid will now be capable of responding to sound, light and touch. From week 26 it is possible that the baby could survive outside the womb, albeit with intensive medical care. Closer to the time of birth the baby should position itself head down and lower down the abdomen.

You partner

Your partner will likely be in serious discomfort, so you’ll be called upon to help out even more. Resting will be difficult and she will have to sleep on her side. She will probably be nesting too, so expect demands to move things around or instruction to have the place tidier than normal. Ailments could include constipation, varicose veins, hemorrhoids, shortness of breath and swollen ankles. Her bladder will have pressure on it, meaning frequent trips to the bathroom. She’ll probably also experience Braxton Hicks contractions – a brief tensing of your partner’s tummy. They aren’t a sign of the onset of labour, just a normal part of pregnancy.

You

Yes, you get to be involved now. Start to talk to the baby, if you haven't already. It can feel a bit strange at first, especially if you're trying to think up something to say on the spot. You could try reading something aloud next to the bump. Children's books are good because they’re easy to read and act out. If you feel awkward doing this, then try humming songs. You'll be doing plenty of singing when the baby arrives, so getting practice in now can't hurt. Hopefully your partner will think this is all cool and not weird.

bullets.content: Antenatal classes
Hitting the due date
Unusual abdominal pain
Vaginal bleeding
Chronic nausea or vomiting
Waters breaking too early

sections.content:
Buying a car seat

As a parent, your first job is to make sure that your baby is as safe as possible. A good, safe, properly installed car seat is part of this.
You’re likely to need two types of seat in your baby’s first year and a half. When choosing a car seat you use weight and height as a gauge, not age.
You use a rear facing seat from birth. By the time your baby is about 13kg, it will most likely have outgrown rear facing car seats and you’ll need to switch to a front facing one.
You should keep your baby in a rear facing seat as long as possible, but its head should never reach the top of the seat.

As usual with baby equipment, the choice can be overwhelming at first. Be practical, do research online, and buy from a reputable source. Take the advice of relatives and friends who’ve recently had kids on the car seats that they’ve used.
Things to keep in mind

Head-hugger or a head cushion

Helpful to support your baby’s head in the early months.

Fitting service

Consider buying from a source that also offers to install it for you. Most car seats are manageable on your own but it might be worth checking all the same.

ISOFIX

This is an international standard for fitting car seats. You should check if your car(s) supports this standard. Some older cars don’t. Although many seats also fit to adult seat belts, ISOFIX is recommended.

UN-ECE

Your car seat needs to be compliant with EU and UN safety standards.
Warning Signs:

bullets.content: Always make sure that the seat is fully secure. Check it regularly for defects, damage or stress on any of the fixtures.
Never install a rear facing baby seat in the front seat of a car without first disabling the airbag. It’s very dangerous and illegal.

sections.content: Don’t buy a second hand car seat. You can’t be guaranteed that it’s still safe. Buy straight from a store to ensure that you’re getting a product in good condition and in perfect working order.

Fit the seat in advance of going to the hospital. They can be tricky and you don’t want to be fussing around trying to fit a seat when your partner is waiting for you to pick her up and take her home.

Sleeping Cots and baskets

Newborn babies eat, cry and sleep. The more they sleep, the less they do the other two things. So getting the right shut-eye gear is essential.

Baskets

Moses baskets are useful for the first month or so. They’re portable and usually have a stand that folds away. However, they will be outgrown quickly and they can be expensive. If you’re thinking about using one, you could consider either borrowing one or buying secondhand.

Cots

Your baby is probably going to be sleeping in this for quite some time. It’s worth putting some thought into your purchase. Here’s the Daddyo cot checklist:

Does it comply with all EU standards?

As with everything that you purchase for your baby, check that it is safety compliant. If you’re buying secondhand, make sure that the model you’re buying hasn’t been recalled due to safety concerns since its original purchase.

Check the size

You want a cot that’s both big enough for your baby’s needs and fits within the space you have available. Measure your nursery before going out to buy. You might choose to have the baby in your room for the first few months, so you’ll have to consider how much space there is beside your bed.

Is a mattress included with the cot?

Most new cots, or cotbeds, will come with a mattress made to fit it. If you’re buying a secondhand cot, buy a new mattress. Whether your mattress comes with the cot or is bought separately, confirm that it is:

Does the cot feel sturdy and durable?

If you’re buying flatpack make sure that you’ve had the opportunity to look at a fully built show unit.

Does it have a drop down side?

A drop down side can be convenient for access but make sure that it is fully safety compliant, with a lock in the lower position. Frequently check that the mechanism is in good working order. Cots with drop down sides have been banned in the US since 2011. They are still available for sale in the EU, as long as they have met certain safety criteria.

Height adjustable?

A convenient, useful feature.

bullets.content: Flame resistant.
The correct size for your cot.
And comfortably firm.

sections.content: Cotbeds - these are cots that convert into small beds, either by simply removing the sides or by more complex re-configurations. Yes, they can be more expensive but your toddler could be sleeping in it for a number of years. Before you buy, make sure to have had a good look at the cot both in its normal and converted state.

Baby sleeping bags - these are recommended. They’re better than duvets or pillows, which can restrict the baby’s movements and make them too warm. And at the same time, they can’t be kicked off and they help prevent your baby getting their feet caught in the bars of the cot.

Keep in mind:

Cost

Buggies can be expensive. How much you spend on one is up to you and your partner. Consider buying secondhand if you can find one in good condition.

Safety first

Whether buying from a shop or secondhand always make sure that the buggy complies with proper safety standards.

Research

Talk to friends and family who’ve had kids recently. Find out what’s worked for them. If you get a chance, try out a friend’s buggy for yourself. (Even better if there’s a helpful kid already in it.) Do your own research online on the model you’re thinking of buying. Time spent researching will save time in the buggy shop, and that’ll be time well spent.

Use from birth

Most buggies can’t be used from birth. You’ll need to check with your retailer to assess suitability.

bullets.heading: Size
bullets.content: Is the buggy going to fit in your car boot? Three wheelers in particular take up a lot of room.

bullets.heading: Ease of folding
bullets.content: Can you easily collapse or fold the stroller? Do you need both hands to do it, or can you do it with one? These are important questions because with one arm holding a baby many simple-seeming tasks become very tricky. Foldability is also critical if you take public transport regularly.

bullets.heading: Lifestyle
bullets.content: If you and your partner have an active, outdoorsy lifestyle you’ll probably want a stroller that can take some punishment and that is maneuverable. Ask friends with similar habits what models they’re using.

bullets.heading: Five point harness
bullets.content: These are the safety belts that keep the kid securely in the buggy. The harness goes over your baby’s shoulders, around the waist and between the legs. Make sure your buggy’s got them, and that they’re good.

bullets.heading: Brakes
bullets.content: Even if the model you’re looking at has a good safety record, check the brakes on the actual one that you’re buying and make sure you’re satisfied. Kick the tires, metaphorically.

bullets.heading: Adjustable handles
bullets.content: Essential for if there’s a big difference in height between you and your partner. Even if there isn’t, this is still a very useful feature to have.

bullets.heading: Add ons
bullets.content: Check to see what’s included in the price. Usually the nice-to-have extras, including rain covers and sun umbrellas, are sold separately.

bullets.heading: Guarantee
bullets.content: If you’re buying from new, try to look for a local retailer that offers more than a one year guarantee. Strollers are an expensive purchase and having confidence that you can use the same one for child number two is an advantage.

bullets.heading: Travel systems
bullets.content: A great solution for newborns. You get portability and easy switching from pram to car seat. You’ll need to check if separate adaptors are needed to correctly fit the car seat.

bullets.heading: Buggy/stroller
bullets.content: Not suitable from birth but a good all rounder. Usually lower cost and reasonably compact.

bullets.heading: Three Wheeler
bullets.content: Bulkier and trickier to fold, which can be a consideration for public transport, but a lot more maneuverable when you’ve got it set. Great for active lifestyles.

sections.content: If you’re going to the shop to have a look at your options, avoid busy shopping times. You’ll be able to spend a more time with the retail staff and probably be able to give the strollers a better going over.

Hospital bag checklist

Your partner’s midwife will probably advise you on what she should bring to the hospital. She might warn you about bag size restrictions in place at the ward. You’ll likely get a handout at antenatal class too.

Pack all items for the labour ward in their own bag. It makes it easier to find what you need without having the stuff for the ward in the way.
Also, you don’t know how long your partner’s stay in hospital is going to be. Make sure that you know where all the spare clothes, pads and baby things are at home in case the stay is longer than expected.

bullets.content: All her toiletries
Toothbrush & toothpaste
Hairbrush
Soap
Any other essentials
Medication – If she’s taking any.
Maternity pads – About 24-30 of these. You can get them in the supermarket.
Towels – Fresh clean ones.
Clothes – Bring several changes of loose, comfortable clothes for labour.
Underwear – Five or six pairs of comfortable pants.
Supportive bras – Including nursing bras if your partner is going to breastfeed.
Homecoming outfit – Something loose and comfortable for your partner to wear coming home
Baby vest
Onesies
Nappies – a packet to be sure
A baby blanket

sections.content: Bring spares of everything. Newborns puke a lot, and new parents can be a bit clumsy changing nappies.

bullets.content: Wash bag
Cash and small change – You don’t want to be looking for an ATM or short of change for a vending machine or for parking.
Snacks – You’re going to be there for a while.
Chewing gum – Fresh breath and you won’t grind your teeth. Win win.
Medication – If you’re taking any.
Chargers – For your phone, iPad, camera and whatever other gadgets you have.
Video camera – If you and your partner have agreed to film the birth.
Warm clothes – Labour rooms can be very chilly. Have something clean and warm to wear.
A pillow – If you’re hanging around, or spending the night on an uncomfortable cot a decent pillow can make a big difference.
Change of clothes – Including socks and underpants.

sections.content: Labour can be a pretty nervy, tense time. But there can also be a lot of waiting around. Distractions can help. Bring entertainment. Anything from podcasts to comics to books to new games on your phone to films and TV shows on your tablet. Install a heap of things that you think might appeal to you and your partner. Don’t count on catching up on TV shows – you’re there to help out.

Phones are pretty unsanitary. If you’re planning on capturing the birth with your phone you should probably use some form of antiseptic wipe on it and wash your hands. You should also check with the hospital that it’s permitted to use your phone to record or photo. There may be restrictions.

Labour

This phase is all action. And sometimes, a fair bit of waiting around too.
The baby is ready to go. Hopefully it happens on, or near, the due date. However, early or late births are not uncommon. Unfortunately, every woman’s labour is different so it’s hard to give hard and fast rules.
Also, you’re probably not going to be required to drive at breakneck speeds to the hospital. Early labour usually gives you plenty of time to drive safely.

The Baby

The baby will be born head first, or legs first (breech birth).
Normal birth weight is between 6lb and 9lb.

The Mother

There are three stages to labour

bullets.content: Latent – Contractions start and then come at intervals of 5 mins and last for 30 seconds. While is is going on, the cervix is dilating to 3/4cm. This can take quite a few hours. So be patient.

Active – Contractions get stronger and become more frequent. They’re also likely to be quite painful. Cervix dilates to 6-7cm. By now you’ll be at the hospital and you partner will have an internal examination to assess the baby’s position.

Transition – The time between contractions decreases, often to the point that it feels like there’s no break between them. Your partner may start feeling the need to push. At this point the cervix should be fully dilated.

For first time mothers, the latent stage can last more than eight hours, although it is unlikely to last for more than 18. This reduces to an average of five hours for women who’ve given birth before.
The cervix is fully open at 10cm.
Her waters should break naturally.
There’ll be very strong contractions every 2-3 minutes. They may feel constant.
Your partner has to push. This will last some time and will be exhausting for her. Your job is to support her.
The baby is born.
The midwives will take the baby aside briefly for some medical checks, to ensure that windpipe is clear and the baby is breathing correctly.
Congratulations.
The womb contracts, and the placenta exits. You’ll probably be distracted with the new arrival, but your partner still has to push the placenta out.
Any vaginal tearing will be repaired. Yes, tearing. It’s also common for women to have an episiotomy, which is a surgical cut to the vaginal wall to aide childbirth.
Contractions
Getting to the hospital
Internal examination
Waters breaking
Full dilation
Total agony
Meeting your kid

sections.content:
What’s happening

The neck of your partner’s womb is opening up in preparation for the birth. This is the first stage of labour, called early labour. And there’s no need to panic. Really. It can go on for a while. It’s likely that your partner will know herself that labour is starting but you should be aware of the signs too.

Hang on, because it’s all about to go a little nuts.

How to recognise early labour

Strong, long, regular contractions

The most reliable sign that pregnancy is starting. Your partner’s womb is tensing and then relaxing. These are going to be a lot more pronounced than the Braxton Hicks contractions. If the contractions are lasting 30-60 seconds and are at 5 minute intervals, time to get in contact with the hospital or midwife, and go grab your contraction kit.
Don’t be over eager. If you get to the hospital too soon, you may just be sent home again. Stick to the plan. Time the contractions and if in doubt call the midwife or the hospital.

A show

This is when the mucus that is plugging the cervix comes away. It’s a blob of jelly like stuff, possibly with some blood in it. It’s not always obvious, and for some women it doesn’t come away until much later in labour. If it does happen, call the midwife or hospital. They’ll probably tell you to stay put but best to check in.

A show is evidence that the cervix is starting to open. Labour can follow immediately or it can take a few days. It’s a wait and see situation. Nevertheless, it’s time to double check the hospital bags.

Warning sign

A little blood in the show is fine and to be expected. If there’s continued bleeding though, call the midwife or the hospital.

Waters breaking

This is amniotic fluid draining from the vagina. The baby has been growing in what’s called an amniotic sac. When the membrane breaks the fluid comes out the vagina. It can either be a sudden a gush or just a trickle. It’s the traditional sign of labour starting but in many cases it doesn’t happen until much later in labour.

Warning sign

Amniotic fluid is a little yellowish and actually looks a lot like urine. It might have a little blood in it to begin with, but not much. Extra blood means you need to seek medical advice.

Warning sign

If your partner’s waters break, and there’s no other signs of the onset of labour, call the midwife or hospital. Without the protection of the amniotic sac the baby may be at risk of infection. It’s likely you’ll be told to wait for 24 hours and after that point the baby may be induced. But call, and get advice.

When D-day is getting near, keep a towel on standby. It’s also not a bad idea to put some plastic sheeting on the bed in the last week or so of the pregnancy. And don’t forget to throw a covering into the car to protect the seats.

Backache

Technically backache can be a sign that labour is starting. But since your partner may already be suffering from back pain, it’s probably nothing to get over excited by.

Toilet emergency

Sometimes the baby pushes down on the bladder as it moves into position for birth. This can mean that your partner needs to rush to the toilet. Again, this could be happening a lot anyway.

title: What do you do for the birth?

sections.content:
What do you do for the birth?

Most women like the idea of having their partner with them in the delivery room. It’s common to the point of expected these days. You and your partner should agree whether or not you are to be present at the birth.

It can get pretty hair in there, so if you decide that it’s not for you, your partner can ask that another family member – for instance her mother or sister – attend instead. Alternatively, she can be attended by a doula instead.

bullets.content: Follow the birth plan.
Try to remain calm for your partner’s sake.
Be supportive.
If your partner has specific medical requests reiterate them to the medical team.
Think of yourself as a personal assistant to your partner.
Stay in, or close by, the hospital (if that’s where you’re planning to have the birth).
Try to stay occupied or distracted, which can be difficult.
Keep the relations informed.
Follow the instructions from your antenatal classes. Ask the midwives where you should stand or what to do if you’re not sure. They’ll tell you anyway if you’re getting in the way.
If your partner doesn’t opt for an epidural, it may seem like she is being tortured. Do not panic, stay levelled headed and calm .
Follow the medical staffs’ instructions to the letter

sections.content:
Newborns can look pretty strange, have wrinkles or even cone heads. They change their appearance very quickly over a few days. Be tactful about how you react. If you think about making some crack about how weird the baby looks, keep it to yourself. Your partner has just done a lot of work to get this kid here in one piece.
Don’t worry – it’ll start looking like a normal baby pretty soon.

bullets.content: Stopwatch or other precise timer with a simple mechanism
A contractions chart with a column for contraction, time started, duration and a space for notes
A pen

sections.content:
The job

Your partner will probably be aware of what to expect from contractions. Each contraction will start, peak, and then subside.
If she gets a few in a row in a regular pattern, start timing them. It’s probably the onset of labour.

bullets.content: Start the timer at the beginning of a contraction.
Jot down the contraction number (1,2,3…) so you can keep track of how many contractions she’s had, and the exact start time.
When the contraction subsides, stop the watch and mark down the total duration of the contraction.
Repeat this process for every contraction.
If there’s pain, or any changes between contractions write them down as additional notes.

sections.content: The time between contraction start times is the interval between contractions. You can recognise labour because these intervals will start to get shorter and the contractions will become more intense.
When contractions are 3 to 4 minutes apart, and have a duration of 45 to 60 seconds, it’s time to get to the hospital.

False contractions – contractions that are not signs of labour starting –  do not follow a recognisable pattern. They may also disappear if your partner shifts position. Labour contractions won’t. Once they start, they won’t quit till the baby’s out.
You might consider having a backup contraction timing kit in the car or in the hospital bag so that it’s close at hand should you need it.

bullets.content: Don’t leave this checklist till the last minute. Make sure that you’ve prepared a couple of weeks in advance of the due date.
Know the route to the hospital from common places you might be.
Know what parking is available at the hospital or nearby.
All the important numbers you need are in your phone contacts AND on a paper backup.
Car seat is properly installed in the car. (There’s a good chance you’ll be going home alone for a few days after the baby is born so you might have a chance to install it then too.)
Hospital dad-bag is packed (including change for parking meters).
Hospital lady-bag is packed.
Contractions kit: Stopwatch, contraction chart and pen.
Freezer and fridge well stocked with easy to cook, nutritious food.

sections.content:
Why are babies born late?

Labour usually starts when the time is right. Every pregnancy is different and a late birth, especially the first time around, isn’t uncommon. Your baby isn’t officially late until two weeks after the actual due date.
Unless there’s a clear indication that the baby is in trouble of some sort, your hospital or midwife will probably recommend letting nature take its course.
However, you’re probably pretty fed up with everything at this point, so there are some things that you can try, which vary from the science based to the old-wives tales.
None of them are reliable, so occupy your mind and find something useful to do:
What to do?

Cook

Use the extra time to cook a lot of freezer ready food. You’ll be congratulating yourself on your foresight after the birth.

Plan stuff to do

Box sets, walks, evenings out, friends over, books, video games. Do things together, and with other people. No need to get too adventurous – your partner could still go into labour at any time.

Relax

Send your partner off for a gentle massage somewhere or run her a bath. And if you have the time, catch up on sleep.

Work

Alternatively, work. If you’ve got a lot on your plate, doing more before the birth might give you a little extra space after it.

What helps to bring on labour?

Not much. There’s a lot of advice out there on the internet. It’s all pretty much nonsense. Some of it is benign, some of it is ill-advised and some of it is ridiculous. Stick to the following:

Sex

Semen contains prostaglandin which softens the cervis. Sex also causes the release of oxytocin, which is linked to contractions. Don’t try this if your partner’s waters have already broken.

Light Exercise

A walk around a park might work. Even if it doesn’t, at least you got out.

You’re a Daddyo!

Congratulations. For the next few weeks you’re probably going to be on an amazing, constant buzz. But don’t get carried away; the first three months can be pretty tough. Expect sleepless nights and a lot of adjustment. It’s non-stop feeding, crying and changing nappies – repeat. But the positives are going to blow the negatives away.

The baby

Development happens quickly. At first they won’t be able to support the weight of their own head. Newborns probably won’t roll over, but might turn from their side to their back. They’ll become more active over time, learning to stretch and kick.
After a few weeks they’ll respond to loud noises, and especially the sound of your voice. They will stare at faces, and often examine their own hands and feet.
By three months they can easily be distracted by unusual sights or sounds. You will be impressed by all of this.
As well as crying, newborns start to communicate by smiling and blowing bubbles. By about two months, they will try to copy your facial expressions and reach their arms out when they want to be held.

Your Partner

Many women get the baby blues – they feel emotional and weepy immediately following the birth of the baby. This can last for a couple of hours or a few days.
Add on the physical effort that labour required, the demands of feeding, and the general caregiving involved in the early stages of the baby’s life you understand if your partner is often tired and irritable and maybe even overwhelmed. It should be expected.

While that’s all normal, be conscious that some women suffer from Post-natal depression.
Symptoms include, tiredness, sadness, feelings of inadequacy and nervousness. If you suspect that your partner might be suffering from mild or severe PND get advice from your GP. It’s a medical condition caused by hormonal imbalance and she might need some help.

bullets.content: Mastering feeding.
Mastering nappy changing.
Mastering bath time.
No improvement in controlling their head over time.
Floppy limbs
Not gaining weight
Not responding to loud noises or visual cues
Not able to focus on your eyes

sections.content: Your Daddyo welcome home checklist
Here’s what you’ll need to make homecoming comfortable for your partner and your new arrival.

bullets.content: Clothes – Clean and loose fitting
PJs – Several pairs
Maternity towels – Several packs
Underwear – Clean and comfortable
Hemorrhoid clean and wipes (just buy it and don’t ask questions)
Squirty bottle – Can help with bathing and relieve stinging
Lanolin – If breastfeeding. Your can get this is in the chemist
Ice packs – For swelling
Nursery – Kitted out, clean and tidy
Feeding equipment – Bottles, steriliser, formula if bottle feeding
Clothes – Suitable for newborns
Nappies – Suitable for newborns
Baby clothes – Including onesies
Baby wipes

sections.content:
House

Make sure that the house is clean, warm and in good shape.

Food

Have at least a week’s worth of food in the fridge and freezer.

Car seat

Properly installed and ready for use.

Family visits

If you have lots of family and friends, make a staggered plan for them to visit so they don’t all show up the moment you get home. You might want to leave the first day free for just the three of you.

Suit yourselves on this one but try to strike a balance between welcoming people in and giving you and your partner some space. You should be the gatekeeper on this one but prioritise (the new) grandparents, siblings and closest friends. Don’t let anyone with cold or flu symptoms around newborns.

You'll be fine…

Holding your baby for the first time is an extraordinary feeling. It’s also terrifying. However, as with everything to do with kids, what’s strange at first becomes second nature very quickly.

General rules

Always support the baby’s head. Newborns can’t support the weight of their own heads, so this is really important.

Keeping the head above the tummy aids digestion and can help prevent wind.

Be calm and confident holding the baby.
Talking will relax the baby while you hold it.
Daddyo holds

The classic

Support the baby with one arm under it’s bottom, use the other hand to support its head and hold the baby against your chest and shoulder. This is also the basic winding manoeuvre.

Arm crook

Hold the baby in the cook of your arm, its head supported by your upper arm and chest. You can use your other arm for extra support if it’s needed. The kid will just curl up and sleep, if you’re lucky.

Facing front

Hold the baby with its back against your chest, placing one arm under the baby’s bottom and the other on their torso. This is a great when your baby needs a little distraction because they can see everything going on around them.

Leg prop

When you’re sitting, pull up your knees and prop the baby up with its head on your lap and its feet on your stomach. Good way to play.

Colic hold

Put the baby face down on your arm with their head towards your elbow, tummy on the palm of your hand. Lowering your arm, so that their head is above their stomach. It can help wind them.

bullets.content: Changing mat/changing table
Nappy – correct size
Baby wipes
Baby powder
Spare clothes
Plastic bag or nappy bin

sections.content:
The Job

Daunting but very doable. Young babies will need changing up to twelve times a day, so you’ll get plenty of practice.

  1. If you’re using a changing table NEVER leave the baby unattended.
  2. Unfasten the old nappy by pulling on the tabs.
  3. If there’s poo, use the old nappy to wipe off most of it as you take it off.
  4. Disposable nappies can be rolled and resealed.
  5. Put it in the nappy bin or plastic bag.
  6. Use the baby wipes to get the rest of the poo.
  7. Even it there’s just pee, you still have to do a good job cleaning.
  8. Clean girls from front to back to avoid getting bacteria in her vagina.
  9. Wipe boys from front to back making sure to clean around the scrotum and penis.
  10. Place the fresh nappy under the baby with the tabs facing up.
  11. Pour baby powder around the genitals to avoid nappy rash.
  12. Pull the front of the nappy over the baby.
  13. Fasten one side of the nappy, then the other.
  14. Fasten the nappy so that it won’t come off but isn’t so tight that it could cause discomfort.
  15. Put the baby in a secure place.
  16. Wash your hands or use antibacterial handwash.
Don’t get oil, lotion or any moisture on the nappy’s sticky tabs as they may lose their stickability.

Nappy rash

A pretty common affliction that most babies will get at some point in their first 18 months, and some babies have more sensitive skin.

bullets.content: Not changing the nappy after a poo or wee.
Chemical in disposable nappies.
Chafing soaps that are too irritating.
Not drying the baby properly after a bath.
Baby wipes.
There’ll be red patches on the baby’s bottom.
Sore or aggravated looking skin.
The skin is hot to touch.
Other blemishes, including spots and blisters.
Change nappies as soon as possible.
Make sure to clean everything really well.
Use baby powder to soak up extra moisture.
If your baby seems to frequently get nappy rash, consider using a barrier cream, which you can get from your pharmacist.
The best treatment is prevention, so follow the steps above.
Use a nappy rash cream, which you can get from your pharmacist.
Put the baby on a towel leave it nappy-less for as long as possible to let air at the sore areas.

sections.content:
Warning Sign

A persistent rash could be something other than nappy rash. A bright red, moist rash with little pimples could be thrush. Check with your pharmacist or GP.

Breast or bottle

Breast feeding is generally considered the best way to go but there can be good reasons why your partner might choose to bottle feed instead.
Breast

bullets.content: Health benefits for baby and mother.
Helps mothers lose pregnancy weight.
It’s efficient for waste and there’s much fewer nappy changes.
It can be painful for your partner – her nipples can get sore or her breasts can become engorged.
Risk of mastitis.

sections.content: Bottle

bullets.content: Anyone can feed the baby.
None of the downsides to breast feeding.
None of the upsides to breast feeding.
Babies are more prone to colic (intense crying).
A lot of stuff to carry around. Although, you probably will switch to bottle at some point so this is only a short term con.

sections.content: Breast milk can be pumped and stored for feeding by bottle. Which means that you can get a turn, Daddyo. Introduce this at around four weeks. It’s much harder to get an older baby to start with bottle feeding.
If in doubt as to what you want to do, best to start with breastfeeding as you can always switch to bottle feed afterwards.

Sterilising bottles

Sterilising your baby’s feeding equipment is vital in preventing potential infections.
You can either use a sterilising solution or an electric steriliser, which is probably more convenient but is also more expensive.
Using sterilising solution

bullets.content: Used bottles and teats
Sterilising solution
Bottle brush
Cold water
Big container
Floating cover for the container
Using the bottle brush, wash the bottle and the teat in hot soapy water, the sooner after a feed the better.
Rinse everything in cold water.
Mix the sterilising solution with cold water in the container, following the solution manufacturer’s instructions on the label.
Place the bottle and the teat in the solution, making sure there’s no air trapped in the bottle.
Use the floating cover to keep everything submerged.
Leave everything in the solution for at least 30 minutes.
Change the solution every day.

sections.content: Electric steriliser

bullets.content: Used bottles and teats
The steriliser
Using the bottle brush, wash the bottle and the teat in hot soapy water, the sooner after a feed the better.
Rinse everything in cold water.
Place all the equipment in the steriliser with openings and/or teats facing downwards.
Follow the manufacturer's guidelines on how long to leave everything in the steriliser.

sections.content: In a pinch you can sterilise by boiling the equipment in water. However, this will eventually damage the teats and Daddyo recommends avoiding it. If you are boiling to sterilise, make sure that you repeatedly wash your hands and use the bottle directly after sterilisation. In general, the other two methods above offer better safety and convenience.

bullets.content: Clean worktop
Sterilised bottle + teat
Formula
Kettle
Fresh tap/drinking water
Boil the kettle. Use fresh tap/drinking water each time.
Let it cool for 30 minutes.
Follow the guidelines on the formula container.
Fill the bottle with the exact amount of water required.
Add in exactly the amount of powder recommend on the formula container.
Put on the lid and shake it until it’s well mixed.
Fill a bowl or other container with hot water but don’t fill it to the top of the container.
Put the bottle in the container to heat it up. ONLY use this method to heat the bottle. No microwaves. Ever.
Test the heat of the milk on your wrist. It should feel a little warm but not hot.
Position the baby comfortably in your arms. Her head should be higher than her body.
Hold the bottle at an angle so that the teat is filled with milk. Put it fully into her mouth.
She may stop and start feeding several times. Take your time and do your best to  get her to take the whole bottle.
If she’s done feeding, get rid of any formula that she did take. There’s too much of a risk of bacteria.
Feeding should take about 20 minutes but that’s a guideline not a hard and fast rule.

sections.content: Timers are your friend. Set countdown on your phone for 30 mins as soon as you turn the kettle on.
Change you holding position a few times during the feed. This helps keep the baby focused on the task at hand and it'll give you arms a bit of a break.

Get a few formula holders. Fill them with the right amount of powder you need. Fill a few bottles with boiled and cooled water. Now you have a baby feeding travel pack; all you need it a friendly person to give you a container of hot water to heat up the bottle.

bullets.heading: Refusing to feed
bullets.content: This might be OK, or a sign that something is wrong. If the baby has missed two or three feedings and seems uncomfortable, it’s probably best to head to your GP.

bullets.heading: Vomiting
bullets.content: Babies vomit a lot. This is often due to swallowing air during feeding. They could also have a bout of gastroenteritis, which they should fight off in a day or two. If you baby is vomiting, monitor its temperature and contact your GP if you’re concerned. Persistent vomiting can be a sign of something more serious, including meningitis or an allergy. Be cool, but be vigilant.

sections.content:
Winding a baby

When babies are born their digestive tracts are not fully developed. This means that they often swallow air when they feed or cry, which makes their tummy swell and bloat. It’s very uncomfortable for them. This is called wind.
Some babies get wind very frequently, but it should reduce as they learn better control in feeding and their digestive track matures.

Identifying wind

The baby might stop sucking on the bottle before it’s finished. It might squirm, make faces and wail. You may even be able to hear trapped air rattling in its stomach. It might be in extra discomfort when lying flat on its back.

When babies are born their digestive tracts are not fully developed. This means that they often swallow air when they feed or cry, which makes their tummy swell and bloat. It’s very uncomfortable for them. This is called wind.
Some babies get wind very frequently, but it should reduce as they learn better control in feeding and their digestive track matures.

Sitting pat

Put the baby on your lap facing away from you. Lean the baby forward, supporting the chest with one arm and holding the chin in your hand. With your other hand pat or rub the baby’s back gently, but firmly. This has two advantages. Firstly, it’s easy to do when feeding and secondly when they burp and milk comes up it will dribble on them and their bib not on you.

Shoulder pat

Place some muslin cloth on your shoulder. Hold the baby against your chest with an arm under the baby’s bottom for support. With your other hand pat or run the baby’s back gently, but firmly. It may also help to gently bounce on the spot. It may take a couple of tries.

Lap pat

Put the baby face down on your lap. Keeping the baby steady, gently pat or rub it’s back with your free hand.

Sometimes a baby has trouble bringing up wind. It might be either that they don’t need to, or that their immature digestive tract is allowing air further into their stomach. If the baby is still clearly uncomfortable, cycle through all the methods above until the baby does a big burp, which is satisfying for both of you.

title: How to stop a baby crying

bullets.content: Soother
Blankets
Pram or buggy
Bottle
Thermometer
Nappy

sections.content:
Is the baby in discomfort?

Hungry

Even if it’s just after a feed, your baby could still be hungry. Try a feed.

Trapped wind

If your baby is pulling its legs, flailing its limbs along with intense crying, it might have wind. Using one of the winding techniques.

Nappy change

You’ll know pretty quick if your baby’s nappy needs changing. Sniff, recoil, then change.

Nappy rash

Treat with nappy rash creams if suspected.

Too hot/cold

Pay careful attention that your baby’s clothing is appropriate to the environment, and that it is not too warm or cold.

Illness

If the crying is accompanied with changes in behaviour, if the baby is burning up, or there is any other reason that you suspect the kid might be ill, check your baby’s temperature. Fever temperature is anything over 37.5°C.
If you’re in any doubt go to your GP. See warning signs below.

Does the baby need soothing?

Sometimes your baby will just want attention. The following can be helpful:

Cuddle & Hum

The easiest go-to solution. Hold the baby close to you, supporting its head on your chest, one arm under its bottom the other holding its back. Hum or sing gently to the baby and gently pat the baby’s bottom in a heartbeat-like rhythm.

Rocking

In your arms, in a crib, in the pram. Any movement is good. However, don’t use this as a method to lull the baby asleep as they get too used to it and they may become unable to sleep without rocking.

Soother/pacifier

Always make sure you’re sanitising these regularly. Be warned, it’s a tough habit to break.

Colic hold

Put the baby face down on your arm with its head towards your elbow, tummy on the palm of your hand. Lowering your arm, so that its head is above its stomach. This hold can also help with wind.

Walk

The outdoors provides fresh air and a distraction for both of you. Get out and about and stay active.

Distract

Your baby might just be bored – new games or a change of environment can help.

Get naked

Some babies like the feeling of being free. You could try taking off your baby’s nappy and letting it kick about, or pop it in the bath and jump in yourself to play.

Swaddle

The opposite can be true too, tightly wrapping your baby in blankets can make it feel more secure.
Sometimes babies just need to cry it out before they sleep. Try not to get frustrated. Use your best judgement and continue to monitor the baby.

bullets.content: Crying combined with a high temperature.
High pitched and weak crying.
Turning blue.
Difficulty breathing.
Any red-purple rash.
Refusing fluids.
Floppy limbs.

sections.content: Unfortunately, some babies cry more than most. In fact, there might be constant crying for three hours a day or periods of intense crying where your baby looks like it is in pain, but in fact isn’t. It can be a difficult phase, but it’s a natural part of development. It usually eases off after five months. Get to know your baby’s patterns and if you’re in doubt seek advice from your GP.

title: How to give a baby a bath

bullets.content: Changing mat/station
A baby tub (or a sink, in a pinch)
Baby bath thermometer
Baby washcloths/sponges
Baby shampoo
Baby soap
Cotton wool
Fresh nappy
Hoody towel
Plastic cup
Baby oil/cream
Toys
Clean clothes
Room heater, if your bathing area is cold

sections.content:
The job

Stage one – Cleaning

Pick a time when your baby is awake and active.

Make sure that you’re going to have the bath in a warm room. Use the room heater if you have to. Babies are very sensitive to temperature.

Get the temperature of the water right – not too hot, not too cold. Use the baby bath thermometer to judge. Around 37ºC is right.

Put the baby on a changing mat or on your knee and undress them. You can leave the nappy on for now.

Wrap the baby in the hoody towel so that it stays warm until you’re ready to pop it in the water.

Dip the cotton wool in the water and carefully wipe around the eyes, go from the nose out. Use a different cotton ball for each eye to prevent transferring infection.

Use more pieces of cotton wool to clean the baby’s ears. Don’t force the cotton wool into the ear, just wash around it. Never use a cotton bud.

Use a very small amount of the shampoo very gently wash the baby’s scalp and hair.

Use the plastic cup to scoop up a little water and wash the shampoo out of the hair. To avoid getting shampoo in their eyes you can tilt the baby’s head back slightly or place your hand over its forehead.

Dry the baby’s hair with towel.

Now you’re ready for the bath

Stage two – The Bath

Remove the nappy and lower the baby into the water, using an arm to support its head.

Continue to wash the baby using the baby sponges paying special attention to neck, hands, bottom and feet.

Swish water gently around the tub.

Bathing your baby should be a fun experience. As your baby gets older, start to introduce toys and play games. Talk as you wash; it helps babies relax.

When you’re all done, carefully take the baby out of the water and wrap it in the hoody towel.

Never leave a baby alone in water, even for a second.

Finishing up

On the changing mat, carefully pat the baby dry.

Make sure to dry in between skin folds like arm pits, behind knees and around the groin. Check for irritated or dry skin.

You can rub in some baby oil or cream but make sure you do this on a stable surface or on the floor as they may be a little slippery afterwards.

Put on a new nappy.

Put on fresh clothes (on the baby – but you too if it got messy).
If you find that your baby often gets surprised by being put in water and cries, try pouring water on its legs before putting it in the bath. Alternatively, you can bath together.

You shouldn’t bathe a baby until the umbilical stump has fallen off – usually about two weeks after birth. Until then, you should only wash the baby using a clean warm cloth and cotton wool for the face. Using powder around the the stump is a good way to keep the area dry.

You should ‘top and tail’ your baby every day, which means clean their face, neck, hands and bottom. But you only need to bathe the baby two to three times a week. If your baby loves bath time, you can do it more often. Be careful though, bathing can make the skin dry out.

Talk to the Baby

If you’ve never been around kids before it might feel strange to natter away to a baby. It’ll probably feel very natural when you’re holding your own.
Babies understand tones from an early age. Talking to them can soothe and relax them, and of course, it’s good for speech development. But that’s further down the road.

What to do:

Talk a lot – Talking comforts babies and shows that you’re giving attention. Talk whenever you’re doing an activity with the baby, such as bathing, feeding. Even if you’re just nearby, you should chat away.

Say their name – It will be several months before the baby will recognise its own name but the more you use it the faster they will learn. Even though the baby may not realise that the name refers to them, they can still get excited by it. They’ll know that it’s a special word.

Eye contact – Maintaining eye contact is useful for creating a connection between you and the baby as you talk. It’s also an added distraction if you’re trying to do something important at the same time, like change a nappy.

Raise the pitch of your voice – A higher pitch that imitates a female voice, can comfort babies and they naturally connect to it.

Make faces – As you talk, be extra expressive. You will look ridiculous when you do this and you will not care.

Sleep deprivation

The first weeks, and possibly months, can be very disruptive on your sleeping patterns. You’ll learn to live with never having enough sleep.
However, sleep deprivation can lead to postnatal depression for you or your partner, so don’t overlook trying to organise your lives to make it as easy as possible on you both. Talk about it early, and be ready to make compromises and allowances.

Try these tactics

Alternate nights

Take it in turns to handle most, if not all of the night feeds on alternate nights.Yes, it can mean one horrible day running on hardly any sleep, but you get to catch up the following night. Make sure that you use the maximum amount of sleeping time on your night ‘off’. If you partner is breast feeding, you won’t be able to help out much on feeds – but you can still take nappy duty.

Family and friends

Take offers of help from trusted, experienced family and friends. Getting out for half an hour or grabbing a quick nap can have huge benefits.

Work balance

If you don’t have much, or any, paternity leave you and your partner may have to come to an arrangement that allows you to get a little more sleep during the week, with you taking up the slack on the weekends. Don't forget, being unproductive at work because of lack of sleep can create extra stress.
You’ve spent a lot of time getting the nursery ready but for the first while, consider keeping the baby’s bed near yours for nighttime feeds. It’s also the safest place for the baby to sleep.
Watch out for arguments. Lack of sleep can make people ratty. Acknowledge this and don’t let it become a problem. Take care of each other.
Consider taking a multivitamin. They can help keep energy levels up when taken over time.

Caring for your partner

By this point you’ve probably made many adjustments to your lifestyle, and you’ve probably taken over many, if not most, of the household tasks. After the baby is born, you’re on the line to do even more.

In the first few weeks, your partner shouldn’t have to worry about anything other than taking care of the baby and recovering from childbirth.

Food – You should have already stocked the freezer so you’ll have an easy ride for the first week or two. After that, plan simple, easy to cook meals in advance for your partner.

Housework – You both should be comfortable to let things slip a little in the early days. But whatever slack needs to be taken up, you’ll have to do it, Daddyo.

Family Time – Your partner probably has friends or close family that are a big part of her life. Make sure to give her time and space to introduce these people to the baby. If her friend flies into town to visit the baby, get out of the house for a while.

Breast feeding mums

Increase fluids – Taking on extra water, fruit and milk all helps.

Diet – Your partner should maintain a healthy, balanced nutritious diet. Lactating mothers should make sure to eat whenever hungry and not miss meals.

Bottle feeding – After two or three weeks you should introduce breastfed babies to a bottle for nighttime feeding. This will allow you to take up some of the feeding duties and allow your partner more sleep.

Nipple shields – If your partner is breastfeeding, pick these up for her. Breastfeeding can be tough going. It can take time to get the knack, and if the baby is not latched on properly there’s a risk of mastitis, which can be painful. Nipple shields can really help.

Many women want to lose the weight that they put on during pregnancy. If your partner is one of these women, you’ll want her to be careful. Rapid weight loss can be bad for her health, and, if she’s breastfeeding, the baby’s too.</br>Normal rules for healthy weight loss apply – good quality balanced diet, and plenty of exercise (if and when she’s feeling up to it). Most importantly, don’t pressure her into losing weight.

3-6 Months

You should be an old-hand at this now. You’ve mastered the basics. You’ve probably gotten some sleep. And if you’re lucky, you’ve found a routine that working for you and your partner.

The baby

Your baby will now be more active. There’ll be lot more kicking and wriggling and it’ll have much better control over its head movements. You’ll notice how the baby will start to rock back and forth, and towards the end of the six months it’ll probably be able to roll over. They could also be able to sit up by themselves and crawling is probably soon to follow.

Hand eye coordination is going to get a lot better also. The baby will be able to grasp and rattle small objects and is probably putting anything and everything in its mouth. It will also be able to pull things towards it.

At this point, it’ll also be able to recognise familiar faces, follow motion and will likely start to focus on bright colours.
You’ll be introduced to a whole new range of sounds, from squealing to gurgling, and the baby might make noises then wait for you to respond.

Your partner

Things will have settled for you partner too. She should be getting more sleep and probably will be back to her normal self.

bullets.content: Stiff muscles
Their body is floppy
They only use one hand to reach
They don’t have any response to visual cues
They don’t reach for objects or put things in their mouth
Their eyes turn in or out
They don’t laugh or squeal

sections.content:
Playing is an important part of learning for children of all ages. It’s how they grow and develop and learn everything from basic motor skills, to how to communicate.
As your baby gets older and learns how to sit up and interact with the world, your games can become more physical and a lot more interactive.

The Bang Things Together game

Give the baby little wooden or plastic blocks that it can easily grip. Show it how to bang them together. That’s it. That’s a game.

Knee Rides

Put the kid on your knees and bounce it up and down gently. It’s a good one to do with nursery rhymes. Also, learn some nursery rhymes.

Bath Time

By three months you’ll be able to introduce toys into bath time that the baby can hold and play with. You can gently splash around too, if the kid enjoys the water.

Blowing Bubbles

Keeping bubbles on hand at all times is a good idea. After about four months or so the baby will be able to focus its eyes far enough ahead to be entertained by them.

Gotcha!
